title: 108_s2545
content: The "Advance Directives Improvement and Education Act of 2004" includes provisions for Medicare coverage of end-of-life planning consultations, improving policies on advance directives, increasing awareness of end-of-life planning importance, and conducting GAO studies on related issues. Congress finds that 2,500,000 people die in the US annually, with 80% passing away in institutions due to chronic illnesses like cancer and heart disease. A study in 2004 highlighted unmet needs of those dying in institutions, emphasizing the benefits of hospice care at home. The Supreme Court affirmed the right of competent adults to make end-of-life decisions in 1997. The Supreme Court reaffirmed the right of competent adults to refuse medical treatment and emphasized the use of advance directives to safeguard this right. Despite the Patient Self-Determination Act, only 15-20% of the general population have advance directives. Competent adults should complete advance care plans to stipulate their healthcare decisions in case they become unable to speak for themselves. Individuals can protect their right to express their wishes and have them respected by using advance directives such as living wills and durable powers of attorney for health care. The purposes of this Act are to improve access to information about health care options near the end of life, promote advance care planning, engage healthcare providers in disseminating information, and assist in the preparation of advance directives. The Act aims to enhance access to end-of-life planning consultations under Medicare coverage, promoting advance care planning and the use of advance directives like living wills and durable powers of attorney for healthcare. The term 'end-of-life planning consultation' refers to physicians' services involving a consultation with an individual on preparing advance directives, the situations where they are needed, the benefits of a comprehensive end-of-life plan, and identifying resources for state requirements. The text chunk discusses the requirements for end-of-life planning consultations, including the designation of a surrogate decision maker and the physician's willingness to follow the individual's wishes as expressed in an advance directive. It also mentions the waiver of deductible and coinsurance for such consultations. The Social Security Act is amended to waive deductible and coinsurance for end-of-life planning consultations. The Social Security Act is amended to waive deductible and coinsurance for end-of-life planning consultations, as specified in section 1862(a)(1) and section 1861(bbb). Payment for physicians' services under section 1848(j)(3) is also adjusted. Effective January 1, 2005, end-of-life planning consultations will be exempt from deductible and coinsurance, with adjustments to payment for physicians' services. Improvement of policies regarding the use and portability of advance directives. Medicare regulations are being amended to include advance directives in individual records and provide opportunities for discussing related issues. The Medicare regulations are being updated to include advance directives in individual records and allow discussions with trained professionals. Additionally, providers must honor advance directives executed outside the state to the same extent as those meeting state requirements. The text discusses the importance of honoring advance directives in healthcare decisions, even if executed outside the state. It also mentions that these directives should preempt any inconsistent state laws but not override laws that offer more patient autonomy. In paragraph (1), amendments are made to include advance directives in an individual's current medical record. These changes aim to ensure the prominence of advance directives in healthcare decision-making. The amendments include providing individuals the opportunity to discuss information with a professional, recognizing advance directives executed outside the state, and updating language requirements. The amendments allow for the recognition of advance directives executed outside the state, with provisions preempting any inconsistent state laws. The amendments also provide individuals the opportunity to discuss information with a professional. The amendments made by subsections (a) and (b) apply to provider agreements and contracts under title XVIII of the Social Security Act and State plans under title XIX. The effective date specified by the Secretary of Health and Human Services cannot be later than 1 year after the enactment of this Act. If a State plan under title XIX requires legislation to meet the new requirements, it will not be considered non-compliant. The plan is not considered non-compliant if it fails to meet additional requirements before the first day of the first calendar quarter after the state legislature's session following the enactment of the Act. Each year of a 2-year legislative session is considered a separate regular session. Increasing awareness of end-of-life planning through programs to educate on advance directive planning issues. This includes advance directive education campaigns and information clearinghouses. The Secretary will conduct a national public education campaign to raise awareness about planning for care near the end of life, explain the importance of advance directives, and educate the public about hospice and palliative care. The Secretary will use funds to establish national and State-specific information clearinghouses for advance directive and end-of-life decisions through grants awarded to public or nonprofit entities. Grants will be for a 3-year period. Authorization of appropriations is provided. Authorization of appropriations is provided for $25,000,000 to carry out this section. SEC. 6. GAO STUDIES AND REPORTS ON END-OF-LIFE PLANNING ISSUES. The Comptroller General of the United States will conduct a study on the effectiveness of advance directives in healthcare decision-making and submit a report to Congress with recommendations. Another study will be conducted on the establishment of a National Advance Directive Registry. The Comptroller General will conduct a study on the implementation of Medicare coverage for end-of-life planning consultations and submit a report to Congress with recommendations. Another study will focus on the feasibility of a national registry for advance directives, considering privacy provisions from the Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act. The Comptroller General will submit a report to Congress with recommendations on the implementation of Medicare coverage for end-of-life planning consultations, as well as the feasibility of a national registry for advance directives, considering privacy provisions from the Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act.
